history.content:
Well, you're always going to have that feeling until you act to change it. So why not do something about it?

Given those dates I assume you are here from 2016-2020. That's plenty of time to explore what you like and dislike, talk to faculty, work in industry, whatever. But it's not going to change until you actually do something.

I was in a similar position as well. I have no plans or intentions of going to grad school, so I was thinking that my time here is the only time I would be able to do research with Berkeley-caliber professors and PhD students in my life. Well, I was lucky enough to have a research opportunity pop up in my life and I took it. I know it's still not for me in the long term, but I'm enjoying it right now and making the most of what I can during my time here. And that's the best you can do.

children.subject:
I think the student response is very good, but I just want to chime in and say that I think part of OP's post is also alluding to the fact that Berkeley doesn't really publicize the great research and great minds here past the admittedly undescriptive "Number One Public University/CS Program" label that gets pushed at us. I think the students in Cal's EECS program could do a lot with knowing exactly why our program is good--right now students (me included) really only have a vague idea that we have a good CS program, but not what makes it good. I think that having some more visible publicity--not for the sake of ego boosting (for we all know EECS students don't need any more of that), but for the sake of broadcasting the many opportunities available at Berkeley--could do some good. It could connect more great students with great professors, provide inspiration, and ease doubts.

While visiting Stanford's engineering building, I noticed that it had the names of famous professors and notable alumni plastered on its walls, along with their accomplishments. While I did note that it was a very "Stanford" thing to do, those names probably provided needed inspiration to more than a couple students walking through the halls of that building.

history.content:
I often feel like I'm not taking advantage of my opportunity to study CS at Berkeley. We have, without dispute, the best CS program of any public school in the world, and probably of any school period. And I'm abruptly reminded of that from time to time. Today, I was reading Prof. Katz's profile and learned he created whitehouse.gov. Not to mention, he created RAID disk idea which is the core principle of all modern hard disks. Or take Prof. Michael Jordan, statistically the most prolific ML researcher alive. Three of my textbooks were written by Berkeley professors.

I fear that big things are happening here and that for many years after I graduate, I'll come across world-changing advances, made at UC Berkeley in 2016-2020, and think "Why didn't I go talk to Prof. XXX at the time? I walked past his office dozens of times as he wrote a Nobel-prize winning paper / created a new field of computer science on his own."

I have gotten research offers here, but still that feeling persists. Does anyone else get it too?
history.subject: Taking advantage of Berkeley CS
